message: Potentially the biggest development of 2016 was the election of Donald Trump on November 8th. With a new ally in the oval office this year, I look forward to a reinvigorated conservative brand of government that will enable us to accomplish many things in 2017, including rewriting our broken tax code, repealing Obamacare, fixing the nation's crumbling infrastructure, cutting back government waste and misuse of Executive power, expanding our economy, protecting America and our allies such as Isreal through a strong defense as well as having the determination to defeat radical Islamist terrorism. I look forward to achieving big things with our new Administration in 2017, and I wish you all a Happy New Year.

Today, I was sworn in for my third term as a United States Congressman representing California’s 1st district. I am excited to get back to work on behalf of the great people of the North State and I look forward to accomplishing big things for our area in 2017.

While Congress and the President-elect are working on putting Americans back to work and moving our country forward at the start of the 115th Congress, the California legislature’s decision to hire former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder proves they are truly out of touch. Holder was the first Cabinet member in history to be officially held in contempt by Congress in 2012 for withholding information on an investigation – a matter I do not take lightly. This move reeks of desperation in the face of true and substantial change, and it won’t stop us from getting America and California back on the right path. I will work tirelessly with President Trump to reduce burdensome regulations, rebuild American infrastructure and re-institute the rule of law.
I'm joining my colleagues on the House floor momentarily for the reading of the Constitution. Follow along here:

Since Election Day on November 8, 2016, the Obama Administration has introduced 145 new regulations that classify as "midnight rules" totaling $21.7 billion. Today, I supported the Regulations from the Executive in Need of Scrutiny (REINS) Act, and yesterday, I voted for the Midnight Rules Relief Act. Together, these bills give Congress more authority to limit and remove harmful regulations issued by the President. The Midnight Rules Relief Act allows Congress to disapprove of last-minute midnight rules issued by the President at the eleventh hour, while the REINS Act gives Congress the final say by allowing us to vote on any new major regulations before they can be implemented. Now, Congress and President-elect Trump will start with a clean slate when working to get Americans back to work.

Far too often in 2016, the brave men and women who enforce the law across the country didn’t make it home to their families. We lost 135 officers last year, 11 from California with 1, Sheriff Deputy Jack Hopkins, from the first district in Modoc County. I just want to say thank you to all who take the oath to protect and serve. I’ve placed a blue light in my office window to honor #LawenforcementappreciationDay.
Yesterday, I spoke on the House floor in support of our Nation's law enforcement officers to honor Law Enforcement Appreciation Day.
Last night, as my friends in the Senate voted to get the ball rolling on Obamacare repeal, I spoke on the House floor to offer my thoughts on why we should repeal and replace this disastrous law.
I want to wish George H.W. Bush a speedy recovery. My thoughts and prayers are with the Bush family right now.

I was very happy to attend the Presidential inauguration ceremonies today to welcome the Trump family to Washington, D.C. and the White House. I look forward to the opportunity to work with President Trump and Vice President Pence to accomplish big things for California and for all of America. We will work together to bring back jobs, improve our nation’s infrastructure, replenish our military and defense capabilities, and provide better and truly affordable health care options for all Americans.
Today I met with Aubrey Bettencourt of the California Water Alliance to discuss issues of critical importance to our state's future and how we can work together in 2017.

Sites Reservoir is the only project in California that would improve water supply for cities, farms, and the environment. If it were already in place today, California would have an estimated additional 600,000 acre/feet of water so far from this winter alone. This project is crucial for our state and I spoke on the House floor today to highlight its importance.

Today, the President issued a pair of much-needed executive orders to strengthen America's border security and reinforce existing immigration laws. I support these swift and decisive actions that put the safety and security of Americans first.
We've had a productive day as President Trump and Vice President Pence addressed the GOP retreat in Pennsylvania. Together, we will succeed in creating a more prosperous and secure America!

For the first time in history, the Vice President gave an in-person speech at the #MarchforLife. I was proud to march alongside thousands of people from around the country to advocate for the rights of the unborn - those who cannot speak for themselves.

Excessive federal regulations have been a burden on the American economy for too long. This new policy will require agencies to cut two existing regulations for every new one introduced. This will offset costs for new regulations and help to eliminate outdated or harmful regulations that prohibit job growth. I am glad to see that this administration is serious about holding agencies accountable and scaling back the severe over-regulation that has hurt our economy.

Justice Scalia was a strong conservative voice on the Supreme Court for thirty years. Now, I am happy that we will have a new face to fill his seat and carry on his legacy of upholding the original meaning of the Constitution and fighting for the values America was founded on. Neil Gorsuch will be a champion of originalist thought on the bench for many years to come. I support his nomination and my hope is that the Senate will move swiftly to confirm him.

This week, the House of Representatives made significant strides using the Congressional Review Act to permanently remove some excessive federal regulations that are very harmful to our economy. We will continue to target and remove burdensome regulations that hold our economy back.

The government should never have access to a person’s online identity without probable cause. That is why, tonight, I voted to increase online privacy for all Americans by joining my colleagues in the House in supporting the Email Privacy Act. This bipartisan bill updates an outdated law that has enabled federal agencies to access emails and other online content that is over 180 days old without a warrant. This legislation fixes that problem and increases privacy by requiring federal agencies to obtain a court ordered warrant to access an individual’s emails, social media, or other online content stored by internet service providers – regardless of the age of the content.

Today, I got a chance to meet with the good folks from Wildcard Brewery to discuss the problems they face as small business owners, as well as the success they've had in the 1st District. It is important that we cut taxes so that more small craft brewers like Wildcard can grow. They made the long journey from Redding, California, so I was glad I had the opportunity to show them the view of the Washington Monument from the U.S. Capitol. Brewers Association

The recent flooding in the North state and damage to the Oroville dam is a great concern for the safety of our communities in Northern California. I will continue to monitor the situation closely.  Local authorities and safety personnel will be on hand to ensure the proper safety precautions are taken. This further highlights our need for better water storage and infrastructure to help capture this water and increase flood safety measures. Stay tuned for updates as more information becomes available throughout the week.

This Congress, I'm proud to be joining the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee. I look forward to working with my colleagues to build a 21st Century Infrastructure for California and all of America.

Significant flooding is expected tonight in Susanville. The National Weather Service predictions indicate the river could crest as high as 14.1 feet. Residents are advised to take the necessary precautions as quickly as possible, as flooding could occur as early as 10:00pm tonight. I will continue to monitor this situation along with the ongoing situation involving damage to the Oroville dam spillway.

Oroville dam update: My team in California has been meeting with the California Department of Water Resources, the Army Corps of Engineers, and local officials throughout the day in order to have the most up-to-date information regarding the ongoing situation. As of now, DWR is doing everything possible to continue using the main spillway, however the emergency spillway is available if the lake continues to rise. Every expert has assured me that the dam is stable and safe. I will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates as they become available.

Oroville Dam Update:  The California Department of Water Resources has announced that they expect the lake level to rise above the emergency outflow level sometime Saturday. Please pay close attention to emergency services if you are in the Oroville, Biggs, Gridley, Marysville, Yuba City area or anywhere near the Feather River.  The water going out of the emergency overflow will be unrestricted, meaning water will flow in the lower Feather River at nearly the speed it is coming into the lake. This will likely mean significantly higher river levels. DWR hopes that the rate of inflow reduces as this storm passes.  If you are in a low lying or flood prone area please be prepared and pay attention to updates as they become available.

Earlier today, I met with public safety officials including Butte County Sheriff Kory Honea, Senator Jim Nielsen, Assemblyman James Gallagher, DWR Director Bill Croyle, and Army Corps of Engineers Colonel David Ray to receive an update on the Oroville dam spillway incident. Water levels have now over-topped the emergency spillway for the first time since the dam's completion in 1968. As a result, many low lying areas near the Feather River are at risk of significant flooding until the storm passes and inflow decreases. Residents should continue to monitor emergency services and stay tuned for updates.
Video of water flowing over the emergency spillway today at the Oroville Dam. The water will increase the flow of the Feather River but poses no threat of damaging or over-topping the dam.

Update: Due to the emergency evacuation and safety concerns amid the ongoing Oroville Dam situation, my office in Oroville will be closed until further notice. If you have not done so already, residents should head for higher ground and stay tuned to emergency alerts.
I joined with the Butte County Sheriff, CAL FIRE, and the California Department of Water Resources to hold a press conference with the latest info on the Oroville Dam spillway incident.
Today, I sent a letter to President Trump urging that he declare a Presidential Disaster Declaration of a Major Emergency for the Oroville Dam spillway incident.

Watch: White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer talks about my efforts to keep the President updated on the Oroville Dam situation and highlights the importance of infrastructure improvements throughout the nation. Yesterday, I sent a letter to the President urging him to declare a Presidential Disaster Declaration of a Major Emergency in the wake of nearly 200,000 residents being forced to evacuate their homes.

Update: Evacuation Order downgraded to an Evacuation Warning. Residents may now return to their homes, but should remain diligent in monitoring emergency services for further updates. The Oroville Dam main spillway and emergency spillway pose no immediate danger to the surrounding communities, but residents should continue to make emergency preparations and proceed with caution. The situation can change rapidly as the week progresses.

President Trump has declared a federal emergency for both the Oroville Dam event and the flooding in the state caused by the storms in January and February. Thank you President Trump for your prompt approval of these much needed declarations. I appreciate his acknowledgement of our California Delegation letter of request as well as the Governor's request.   THE WHITE HOUSE Office of the Press Secretary FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE February 14, 2017   President Trump Approves California Emergency Declaration                                                                                          The President today declared an emergency exists in the State of California and ordered Federal assistance to supplement State, tribal, and local response efforts due to the emergency conditions resulting from the potential failure of the emergency spillway at Lake Oroville Dam beginning on February 7, 2017, and continuing.   The President's action authorizes the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), Department of Homeland Security, to coordinate all disaster relief efforts, which aim to alleviate the hardship and suffering caused by the emergency on the local population and to provide appropriate assistance for required emergency measures. These relief efforts are authorized under Title V of the Stafford Act to save lives, to protect property and public health and safety, and to lessen or avert the threat of a catastrophe in the counties of Butte, Sutter, and Yuba.   Specifically, FEMA is authorized to identify, mobilize, and provide, at its discretion, equipment and resources necessary to alleviate the effects of the emergency.  Emergency protective measures, limited to direct Federal assistance, will be provided at 75 percent Federal funding.    Robert J. Fenton, Acting Administrator, Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), Department of Homeland Security, named Timothy J. Scranton as the Federal Coordinating Officer for Federal recovery operations in the affected areas.

Yesterday, I spoke on the House floor to provide an update on the Oroville Dam spillway situation. Now that the President has declared a federal disaster, we will continue to focus on providing support for those who were forced to evacuate from their homes. The dam looks stable for now and we will investigate what went wrong once the emergency situation is over.

I want to thank President Trump for his rapid response to this crisis that we are facing in Northern California. The Oroville Dam spillway incident is a very timely situation and requires quick action to provide relief and ensure the safety of our residents. Once the Governor officially requested a disaster declaration, the President responded swiftly and granted it within twenty-four hours of the request. After receiving a phone call from the President, I was able to personally brief him on the situation and provide him with the most updated facts and details available. I appreciate his attentiveness to this ongoing situation and I look forward to working together to improve infrastructure for California and all of America.

An individual's food choices with their own money are no one's business but their own, however I do not believe taxpayer dollars should be used to buy sodas and other sugary items that provide minimal nutritional value. According to a recently released USDA report, more Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) money was spent on soda than any other item, accounting for more than $3.5 billion of food stamp spending per year. Those that rely on SNAP should instead be directed towards healthier alternatives.

Oroville Dam's fragile spillways highlight the importance of flood prevention. We must rebuild and maintain old roads, bridges and levees while also creating new infrastructure projects to help with flood control. I got a firsthand look at some of the work being done.

Yesterday I sat down with local TV stations in Chico and Redding to discuss the Oroville Dam spillway situation. The Dam is safe and sound at the moment, but residents should remain alert and stay tuned for updates throughout the rainy season. We will investigate what caused this issue and I look forward to working with the President and my colleagues in the House to modernize Infrastructure in California.

I enjoyed the opportunity to meet with community members to discuss the path forward for Northern California infrastructure. We had a productive discussion yesterday and I look forward to attending many more community events in the coming months to discuss how we can work with the President to improve our water infrastructure in order to avoid another incident like we've experienced with the Oroville Dam spillway.

Last week, I attended a community meeting in Oroville to address some of the questions and concerns regarding the Oroville Dam spillway situation and to discuss how we can be better prepared in the future.

The Waters of the U.S. is one of the most unconstitutional and far-reaching rules implemented by any Administration ever. Today’s Executive Order dismantles a rule which would give unelected bureaucrats control of nearly every body of water in the country. The WOTUS regulation would have devastating impacts on rural economies and property rights in Northern California. I have fought this rule from the beginning and I am glad to see the new Administration take action to prevent it from taking effect.

Overall, the President’s message tonight was one of positivity and one that I believe will resonate with the American people. He outlined his ideas for the coming months, such as improving American infrastructure, strengthening our military, securing our southern border, improving education for our children and renewing the sense of the American spirit that once united us. I look forward to working with the President on these and other issues that are critical to Northern California. In particular, I am committed to improving our aging infrastructure – an issue only further highlighted by the recent Oroville Dam spillway incident, which the President reacted to in a swift and decisive manner. We must continue down the path of regulatory reform in order to undo some of the overreaching and burdensome regulations that harm our economy. The President has kept his word to foster job growth and create opportunity for those who feel like they have been left behind. Now, it is the responsibility of Congress to work together with each other and with the Administration to create an environment where our economy can truly flourish.

Congratulations to my friend and former colleague Ryan Zinke on his confirmation to Secretary of Interior. He is a good man and a retired Navy Seal. We have already been talking about the issues affecting Northern California and why we need more dams, not less. He will be a great ally for me and the issues important to a vibrant North State.

The President's address to a Joint Session of Congress on Tuesday was one of the best speeches given in that chamber in quite some time. I told him the North State thanks him for his quick response to the Oroville Dam situation and I look forward to working with him to improve California's infrastructure.

For too long, veterans in the North State have had trouble getting access to VA medical care. I’m pleased to announce that the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee will authorize the VA to lease a new facility in Redding, California. This new lease will significantly increase the types of care available for our veterans in the North State, now it is time for the VA to ensure that the facility is properly staffed and these tax dollars are not wasted.

This week, I introduced the American Food for American Schools Act. This bill increases transparency for schools who request a waiver to use foreign products in school lunches and helps to ensure our tax dollars are used to buy American produce and to support American agriculture.

While back in the North State this past weekend, I had the opportunity to tour some of the damage caused by the Oroville Dam spillway incident. This recent flooding is testament to the fact that California needs better water infrastructure. That is why Congressman John Garamendi and I introduced bi-partisan legislation last week to help facilitate construction of Sites Reservoir, which would provide more storage per dollar invested than any other proposed project in the state.

Tonight, the House passed H.R. 1301, the Department of Defense Appropriations Act of 2017. This bill provides the necessary funding to ensure our soldiers are properly trained for combat, properly equipped on the battlefield with superior technology, and properly taken care of when they return home. In recent years, we’ve watched as our military has been denied the support necessary to maintain its tactical edge. Today we voted to raise the pay of our military personnel and allocate funding to support a larger, more advanced reserve force. With tensions high across the globe, we must show the world that America’s military is ready and able to protect us from any who would wish to threaten our sovereignty.

I spoke on the House floor to applaud the President's decision to halt new EPA fuel efficiency restrictions on the auto industry. Fully reviewing these requirements will result in lower vehicle costs, allow for safer vehicles, and boost our economy by supporting domestic manufacturing.

Thank you to all who made it out for the town hall meeting in Grass Valley on Saturday. We agreed on some issues and disagreed on others, but we were able to have a productive conversation on the very important issues we are working on in Congress. I look forward to continuing that conversation with other areas of the North State in the coming months.

This morning, President Trump stopped by the Capitol to discuss plans for health care reform with Members of the House of Representatives. Together, we will deliver on the promise we made to the American people to repeal the ACA and replace it with better and more affordable health care options.

Today, I met with California Governor Jerry Brown to discuss, among other things, last month's Oroville Dam spillway incident. We must work together on the state and federal levels to ensure California's infrastructure is properly maintained and updated so situations like this don't happen again. To speed repairs, I've asked President Trump to exempt repairs from red tape that would drive up costs and cause delays.
Today is National Ag Day. As a farmer, I am proud to serve on the House Agriculture committee, where I can advocate for the essential role agriculture plays in maintaining a strong U.S. economy.
Today, the House voted to level the playing field for small businesses. Read why that is so important:

Today, I met with Colonel David G. Ray of the Army Corps of Engineers to discuss the Oroville Dam incident, the Hamilton City J-Levee project, and other important issues to California's 1st district overseen by the Army Corps.

Yesterday, I served as Chariman on the Subcommittee on Indian, Insular and Alaska Native Affairs Oversight Hearing on The Status of the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority (PREPA) Restructuring Support Agreement. Watch the below video for my opening statements:

I firmly believe that the United States is a country of immigrants. We welcome those who would like to enter our great nation – as long as they do so legally. Sanctuary cities are an affront to our nation’s longstanding immigration laws and potentially jeopardize the safety of our citizens. Those who come here illegally have broken the law, period. Allowing this to continue is unfair to those who have done the right thing and immigrated here legally. I fully support the Administration and Attorney General Sessions as they work to protect our borders and ensure those who enter this country do so legally and safely.

I am happy to see the President move to undo some of the burdensome, job-killing regulations implemented by the previous Administration. Let’s remember that these unreasonable regulations did not come into force because of new laws, but simply because of more executive action. That is why I can applaud the removal of these burdens by executive action now. Under President Obama, the Environmental Protection Agency had gotten out of control – unfairly targeting certain sectors and threatening entire industries. This Executive Order pulls back from the EPA’s overly burdensome Clean Power Plan, lifts a moratorium on new coal leases on federal lands, while also rolling back several other Obama-era EPA regulations that overstep the agency’s authority and place an undue burden on our economy and job growth. This will unleash our country’s energy industry and help enable America to become truly energy independent.

Today, I spoke on the House floor in support of the HONEST Act, which requires that EPA regulations simply be based on science that is publicly available. This should be common sense. Citizens have the right to know how and why the government makes decisions – as well as the ability to challenge those decisions. This legislation is about transparency, taking decision-making authority away from unelected bureaucrats and  allowing Congress – and ultimately the people – to have the final say regarding decisions made by the EPA.

One third of rural Americans do not have access to robust broadband connectivity, including many in Northern California. In a time when we are experiencing significant advances in technology, such as telemedicine, distance learning, or even wireless mobile access, we need to ensure rural communities have the resources needed to keep up. This morning in the House Agriculture Committee, I discussed this issue with representatives from the Farm Credit System and what they are doing to help make resources available to improve rural broadband access.

I am very pleased to announce that my office is now accepting submissions for the 2017 Congressional Art Competition. This year’s theme, The Thin Blue Line, will allow our students to show their support and appreciation for our local law enforcement officers who represent the thin line between order and chaos. I look forward to seeing the submissions for this year’s competition. Visit my website below for entry details.

North Korea’s blatant violations of UN Security Council resolutions present a clear danger to the United States and its allies. As the world sits back and watches, Kim Jong-Un grows bolder – frequently threatening direct attack on the United States. The House sent a clear message today that America will not tolerate such behavior.

Today, I introduced the Electric Reliability and Forest Protection Act with my colleague from Oregon, Rep. Kurt Schrader. This bipartisan legislation allows utility companies to more efficiently remove hazardous trees and other vegetation near a transmission line to reduce the risk of wildfires. A single tree falling on a transmission line can cause blackouts for thousands of homes and spark a fire that devastates a National Forest, but existing red tape can prevent removal of dangerous trees for months. Under our legislation, rural electric co-ops, utilities, and municipal power providers will be able to proactively remove hazardous trees before they become problems, not after they’ve caused a fire.
I had a great meeting this morning with Secretary of Transportation Elaine Chao. Together, we will work to improve California's aging highways and infrastructure.

I am very pleased that the Senate voted to confirm Judge Gorsuch as our next Supreme Court Justice. Now, we will once again have a champion of originalist thought to fill the seat once occupied by the late Justice Scalia. It was clear that those who opposed Judge Gorsuch did so only because he was nominated by a Republican President, and not based on his merits, qualifications, or character. Judge Gorsuch deserved to be confirmed and I fully support the Senate for doing what was necessary to make it happen.

The justification for these airstrikes is clear – the use of chemical weapons on innocent civilians is a truly despicable act. I believe President Trump was right to respond with appropriate military force. The targeted strike shows that America will take action and hold the Assad regime accountable for their acts of terror. Going forward, Congress must be involved in determining our level of military engagement with Syria.

It is irresponsible for the California Department of Water Resources to withhold documents related to the Oroville Dam spillway incident from the public, particularly those who live near the dam and deserve to know whether or not their families are safe. This is a serious matter of public safety and transparency, one that I do not take lightly, and I believe these reports should be released immediately.

The strategy of going on the offensive against the Islamic State is already paying dividends. This strike was well-planned and executed, resulting in significant damage to ISIS infrastructure and defenses. I fully support those who are fighting to defeat radical Islamic terrorism.

I was happy to honor Oroville High School Junior Greyson Reynolds for his efforts to restore the Pledge of Allegiance to his school after more than 45 years without it. He saw a problem and took the initiative to fix it. I applaud his patriotism and leadership on this very important issue.

It was a packed house last night for my town hall meeting in Redding. Thank you to all who came out to share your ideas and concerns with me. We had a respectful and productive discussion that helps us all learn. While we may sometimes disagree on certain issues, I'm confident that we reached a lot of common ground that will help me going forward as I represent you in Washington.

I was happy to join Senator Jim Nielsen and Assemblyman James Gallagher for a Community Leaders Breakfast last week in Chico. We will continue to share ideas and work together to create jobs and build the economy of Northern California.

Today, I want to join our ally, Israel, in recognizing Holocaust Remembrance Day. Now, more than 70 years after the unspeakable events of the Holocaust, Iran and the Islamic State wish to replicate the same hatred towards Jews demonstrated by the Nazi party. Anti-Semitism has no place in this world, and the United States must continue to demonstrate our unwavering support for the Israeli people.

Watch Live: I will be joining President Trump and Secretary Zinke at 11:20am ET/ 8:20am PT at the Department of Interior as the President signs a much-needed Executive Order to initiate a review of national monument expansions under the Antiquities Act.

I fully support the President’s decision to review national monuments that had been aggressively expanded under the Obama Administration. Downsizing many of these monuments will help the Department of Interior to better manage our federal lands and allow land owners to better use their own private land. It is time to reform the Antiquities Act and return the power to designate and expand national monuments back to Congress. I look forward to working with President Trump and Secretary Zinke to increase access to public lands and boost rural economies.

It is no secret that our tax code is over-complicated and burdensome for small businesses and individuals alike. As most Americans could attest, the supposedly simple task of filing your annual tax return is needlessly time-consuming and tedious – not to mention expensive for many individuals who enlist the help of outside assistance or services. Our tax code is broken and in need of comprehensive reform. I am glad that the President has presented his priorities and I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress and the Administration to lower taxes and fix our tax code. This will help to stimulate our economy, create jobs, and finally provide some relief for middle-income Americans.

Today, I joined with Congressman John Garamendi to introduce the FARM Cost Reduction Act. This bill keeps the North State’s farm economy growing and lowers costs for agriculture by modernizing federal flood insurance rules that currently place the same requirements on barns and silos as on suburban housing tracts. By recognizing that agricultural structures have different needs than residential neighborhoods, farmers will be able to build new barns, silos, and sheds and purchase insurance at reasonable rates. I am pleased to work with our bipartisan coalition to bring some common sense back to flood insurance requirements.

I am very pleased that my bill, the Electric Reliability and Forest Protection Act, passed through committee with strong bipartisan support. Rep. Kurt Schrader and I have worked together to ensure this legislation moves forward and addresses a real world problem affecting forest health and safety. Our bill removes existing red tape that will allow for more streamlined removal of trees that have potential of falling on a power line and causing blackouts or forest fires. We’ve had strong support from both sides of the aisle along with many local utility companies and power providers located in Northern California and beyond. I’m pleased to see this bill progress through committee quickly and I look forward to a vote on the House floor soon.

Yesterday, the President signed an Executive Order to create an Office of Accountability and Whistle-blower Protection at the Department of Veterans Affairs. For the first time, VA employees will be held accountable if they are found to be guilty of any misconduct or mistreatment of our veterans. Improving the quality of care for those who have served their country is one of my top priorities in Congress. The House has already passed legislation to give VA leadership more authority to remove under-performing employees, and I look forward to seeing the Senate follow suit.

This week I met with officials from Placer County, including County Supervisors Robert Weygandt, Jennifer Montgomery and Jack Duran, County Executive Officer David Boesch, County Legislative Officer Joel Joyce, and County Conservation Plan Administrator Gregg McKenzie. We had a great discussion on several Placer County infrastructure and federal policy priorities for 2017.

42 years ago today, the fall of Saigon marked the end to the Vietnam War after two decades of conflict. While we commemorate this day, we must recognize the sacrifice made by the millions of veterans who risked their lives to protect the freedoms we hold dear and honor the thousands of Americans that never made it home to their families.

Over the weekend, I attended the retirement ceremony for my good friend, Placer County Sheriff Ed Bonner. After 42 dedicated years of service to Northern California with the Placer County Sheriff’s Department, Sheriff Bonner has closed the door on a distinguished career which saw him become one of the most respected members of the community in Placer County. I congratulate him on this much-deserved milestone and wish him a peaceful retirement as he embarks on a new chapter of life alongside his loving family.

Today marks the beginning of National Small Business Week, where we celebrate the small businesses who employ more than 75 million Americans across the country. As a small business owner myself, I understand the the impact excessive government regulations can have on job growth and our economy. We must work to make sure we are helping small businesses prosper, not placing unnecessary road blocks in their way.

Today I received the American Conservative Union’s Award for Conservative Excellence for standing up for conservative values and backing it up with my voting record in 2016. We’ve carried that momentum into the 115th Congress and I look forward to getting a great deal accomplished with our unified conservative government during the remainder of 2017.

Watch: I introduced the Electric Reliability and Forest Protection Act with Rep. Kurt Schrader to help streamline hazardous tree removal and wildfire prevention. Our bill passed through committee last week, and I look forward to a vote on the House floor soon.

Today, the Natural Resources Committee’s Subcommittee on Federal Lands held a hearing on the consequences of Executive overreach of the Antiquities Act. Too often, massive swaths of land have been designated as national monuments without any input from local communities. In the wake of President Trump’s Executive Order to review all monument designations in the last 20 years, I questioned a panel of experts and asked them whether they thought hunting and angling should be allowed on all federal lands where it had been allowed previously. Their answer was a resounding yes.

Today, the House passed the Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2017. There are parts of this bill that are strong positives for the North State and America, while others that I grudgingly have to accept as the price of getting sixty votes in the Senate. This funding bill achieves significant goals of investing in our military and enhancing border security, while also providing for our rural district by including $465 million in payment to offset the vast ownership of our local lands by the federal government that is eroding our local tax base, as well as significant increases in funds for firefighting. This is ultimately an improvement over the past process of using a Continuing Resolution that simply kicked the can further down the road.

Here’s what we know: Obamacare is collapsing. Insurance providers are pulling out of the exchanges, premiums are continuing to skyrocket, and choices for Americans are dwindling – and it will only get worse. From my very first day in Congress, the constituents of Northern California have pleaded that we get this law repealed and replaced with something that actually works for them. We also know that there will be no help from Democrats, forcing us to use the budget reconciliation process which requires only 51 votes in the Senate as opposed to 60 - Republicans have 52 votes. Without budget reconciliation, this bill would need 60 votes to pass and would be dead upon arrival in the Senate – sticking Americans with the high costs of Obamacare for another year. This was our one and only shot to get this done using the budget reconciliation process. The rules of reconciliation force the House to be cautious not to exceed parliamentary guidelines, but the Senate will have significantly more flexibility in their own chamber to test parliamentary limits. Simultaneously, we passed legislation today that will ensure Members of Congress and staff are subject to the same healthcare options as the constituents they serve. The bill protects some of our most vulnerable by ensuring under no circumstance can people be denied coverage because of a pre-existing condition. In fact, it keeps in place many of the current patient protections, such as barring insurance providing from increasing premiums based on health status or gender, while also keeping in place guaranteed issue and renewability, essential health benefits as the federal standard, and the right of dependents to stay on a family plan up to age 26. While States have the option to apply for waivers from certain regulations that increase premiums, the bill makes clear that no State or provider can deny an individual with a pre-existing condition access to health insurance. This bill is not a finished product, but more work will be done in the Senate as well as concurrence on amendments in the House. Constructive input is still welcome, but doing nothing is not an option. The American Healthcare Act is a positive step that will ultimately return the freedom of choice back to the patient.

I met with farmer John Duarte, who faces tens of thousands of dollars in penalties just for plowing his fields because his four-inch furrows were treated as “miniature mountain ranges." This prevents many farmers in Northern California from simply using their land and violates the spirit and intent of the law. We met with the American Farm Bureau and the California Farm Bureau this week and will work with the Administration to ease this excessive regulation.

Today is National Peace Officers Memorial Day and the beginning of National Police Week, where thousands of police officers from around the country gather in the nation’s capital to honor those officers who made the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty. In recognition of Police Week, the House of Representatives will vote on several bills that will help give our men and women in uniform more of the tools they need to successfully protect and serve our communities. Today, the House is voting on the Thin Blue Line Act, which adds the murder of a law enforcement officer, firefighter, or first responder as an aggravated factor for a jury to consider in deciding whether to impose the death penalty in federal capital cases. 135 officers were killed in the line of duty last year, 11 of which were from California – including Modoc County Sheriff’s Department’s own Jack Hopkins. This bill sends a clear message that the murder of a police officer will not be tolerated and that justice will be served. I spoke on the House floor in support of this bill and National Police Week.

Please join me in remembering those who made the ultimate sacrifice – to these brave Americans, we are eternally grateful. God Bless America.

Enjoyed visiting New Auburn Cemetery to honor those who have given their lives so that we can be free on this Memorial Day. We must never forget the true meaning of this day. Thank you to all who have served our country and to those who continue to serve today.

Sites Reservoir would provide more water storage per dollar invested than any other proposed project in California. The benefits are clear. As this graphic illustrates, the construction of Sites Reservoir would dramatically increase water storage in both wet and dry seasons.

Today, I joined Senator Jim Nielsen and Assemblyman James Gallagher in touring Oroville Dam and the Hyatt Power Plant to review progress on the spillway repairs, as well as the refurbishment of the power plant. America’s infrastructure and technology for air traffic control is becoming increasingly obsolete. The federal government has wasted millions of taxpayer dollars while American aviation still lags far behind the rest of the world. Last week, I joined the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee to visit Nav Canada in Ottawa, Ontario – Canada’s privately run air traffic control navigation service that manages 12 million aircraft movements per year. Last month, the committee held a hearing on the future of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and what we can learn from Canada’s safe and successful system as we look to reform the FAA. The U.S. currently has around 250 contract towers, which the FAA has attempted to shut down, despite offering equal safety standards and saving an average of $1.5 million per year, per control tower. Like Canada, the U.S. needs to create an independent, not-for-profit corporation to provide air traffic services – that can still be overseen by the FAA, Department of Transportation, and Congress – and bring American aviation into the 21st century.

These accomplishments represent quality, as well as quantity – cutting unnecessary red tape and regulations, building our economy, and putting Americans first. We will continue working to return health care choices back to the patient, reform our broken and over-complicated tax code, and reaffirm America’s position as the leader of the free world.

Today marks the 73rd anniversary of the Allied invasion of Normandy on June 6, 1944. Operation Overlord, which started with D-Day, was the turning point in the war in Europe and led to the eventual liberation from Nazi occupation. Despite a historic victory, the graphic losses suffered by Allied forces on that day marked the tremendous cost of human life over the course of the entire war. Today we honor the thousands of Allied soldiers who gave their lives to defeat tyranny on the beaches of Normandy.

The President has shown a commitment to improving our nation’s aging infrastructure, and I am appreciative of funding programs intended specifically for rural areas like Northern California. While big cities have more resources to compete for existing federal grant programs, creating a program specifically for rural areas means we have more opportunities to fund projects, such as the expansion of State Route 70 in Butte County and Interstate 5 between Anderson and Redding. This plan would potentially lower costs on significant infrastructure projects to our state, such as Sites Reservoir, while also providing funds for highways, bridges, and waterways that are badly in need of expansion or repair. Additional transformative projects, like wholesale air traffic control reform, will help bring American Infrastructure into the 21st century. I agree with the President that the American people deserve the best and safest infrastructure in the world, and we will work together with the Transportation and Infrastructure committee to make that a reality.

Today I met with Cheryl LaFleur, Acting Chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and urged FERC to rapidly approve new boat launches, parking areas, and other recreational facilities at Lake Oroville to replace those closed during spillway repairs.   While the spillway launch area will be closed for the foreseeable future, replacing those facilities rapidly is key to protecting recreation and tourism in Oroville.     We also discussed the need to keep spillway repairs on schedule to ensure safe operations in the coming winter and protect the dam’s ability to store water for homes, farms, recreation, and flood control.   I’ll continue working with FERC, DWR, and other agencies to keep the repair process transparent and Oroville open for business.

When Dodd-Frank was passed in 2010, it took financial choice out of the hands of consumers and placed it into the hands of Washington bureaucrats. Without a doubt, Dodd-Frank – and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau it created – have hurt the American economy and severely hindered job-growth. It made the biggest banks bigger while often directly leading to the closure of many local banks and credit unions in Northern California. The Financial CHOICE Act will do what Dodd-Frank could not – that’s ending bailouts, protecting consumers, and holding Wall Street and government bureaucracies accountable. Under this bill, no one will be too big to fail, but more importantly, no one will be too small to succeed.

The VA’s arcane civil service rules mean it can take up to a year to fire an underperforming employee, even those that are found to have participated in severe misconduct. Our veterans deserve a VA that is accountable – and can hold its employees accountable. Even former VA Secretary Sloan Gibson admitted last year that it is too difficult for the agency to fire bad employees. Today the House passed the VA Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act, which ensures that a few bad employees won’t unfairly diminish the reputation of the many hardworking people at the department. I am happy the House voted to send this common sense legislation to the President’s desk so that we can start to see real reforms at the VA.

This week, the House will consider my bill – the Electricity Reliability and Forest Protection Act. This bipartisan bill provides streamlined processes for the removal of hazardous trees or other vegetative overgrowth within or adjacent to electricity infrastructure – such as power lines – on Bureau of Land Management and U.S. Forest Service lands, reducing the risk of forest fires and electrical grid blackouts.

Today, the House passed my bill – H.R. 1873, the Electricity Reliability and Forest Protection Act, with broad bipartisan support. Current bureaucratic restrictions and red tape delay the removal of potentially hazardous trees that are near or in contact with power lines, which can lead to blackouts and forest fires. In 2012, 232 wildfires were caused by trees falling on power lines. The following year in 2013, 113 wildfires were caused by fallen trees. This bill streamlines the process for utility companies to remove dead or dying trees that are in danger of falling on a power line or are in need of trimming. It’s just common sense to remove a tree that is dangerously close to a power line. I’m pleased this bill passed the House with bipartisan support and I hope the Senate will soon follow.

In recent years, lack of adequate water infrastructure has caused major problems in California. While it may only take a few years to complete construction of a new project, it usually takes many years – even decades – to fulfill the complex and duplicative permitting processes required by multiple federal agencies. Today the House passed the Water Supply Permitting Coordination Act, which streamlines that process by tasking one agency, BOR, with the responsibility of coordinating all permits, reviews, or other requirements for critical water storage projects.    While this bill applies to projects run by the federal government, I offered an amendment to also include State-led surface storage projects, such as Sites Reservoir. This will allow states to address their own water infrastructure needs without requiring, nor excluding, federal funding, and to allow state projects to also enjoy the coordination that the federal projects would under the bill. Californians want new and better water storage infrastructure, and this bill establishes a framework for that to happen in a faster and more efficient manner, preventing permittees from being caught in the middle of another round of bureaucratic badminton.

With President Trump’s signature, The VA Accountability Act is now law. This strengthens the VA's authority and removes frustrating excuses to hold their employees accountable and fire any bad apples that aren’t looking out for the best interests of our veterans. This is an important step forward in the process of total reform at the VA. I'm pleased that I was able to support and help move this much needed measure through the House. The VA has been slow to follow previous directives I've supported, even in defiance of Congress. Our veterans deserve better care, and we will keep working until we achieve that goal.

The Supreme Court ruled unanimously (9-0) to lift the injunction on President Trump’s travel ban from countries identified as heightened terrorism risks, allowing it to immediately go into effect. The President’s travel ban is necessary and is provided for in the Constitution – despite the rulings of activist judges in lower courts. Contrary to some reports, this policy has nothing to do with singling out a religion and everything to do with heightened risk of terrorism affecting our country. With increased terrorist attacks like we’ve seen in Europe and here at home, the President and Congress need all the tools available to ensure we are not importing terrorism to the United States. This is a victory for the security of our country. The President’s authority to enact this policy is granted under the Constitution, and I expect the Supreme Court will eventually decide to permanently uphold it.

Our immigration system needs a lot of work, but today we start with the obvious – we will not shield unlawful criminals from immigration enforcement and we will not let deported felons back into our country.

The California legislature governs by catering to the ideology of the majority and often ignoring the minority altogether. In the North State, our views don't align with those of the Bay Area and they never will. Excessive regulations and trophy legislation are disproportionately impactful to rural communities and destructive to our economies. We need a state legislature that represents all of California and works with everyone's best interests in mind.

In case you missed it, I spoke on the House floor to highlight the importance of the Secure Rural Schools program. It is imperative that Congress uphold this commitment to our rural communities until we see significant and meaningful reforms in forest management on our national forests.

A few weeks ago, Congress passed the VA Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act, which the President signed into law soon after. Now, Secretary Shulkin is ensuring that the Department of Veterans Affairs is following suit by increasing transparency and disciplining employees for bad behavior. There are many hardworking people at the VA that truly have our veterans’ best interest in mind, but those who don’t must be held accountable. Now we are beginning to see some of the reforms necessary to create a culture of accountability at the department.

I have always been a strong supporter of Oroville Dam’s re-licensing effort. After waiting for many years to finalize the re-licensing agreement, waiting a couple more months for the independent forensic report promised for September is a reasonable request. The citizens of Oroville, Butte County and Northern California are counting on a proper and independent review that is completed, analyzed, and made available to the public. We can’t let the Federal and State entities rush away from the table with a final 50 year agreement before the concerns of our constituents are met.

In February, the Oroville Dam spillway incident threatened the safety of Butte County residents. Now, the Wall Fire has again caused thousands of citizens in Northern California to evacuate their homes. Sadly, some residents won’t have a home to return to, as the wildfire has so far damaged or destroyed dozens of structures. Yesterday, as the situation has begun to improve, I met with some of the firefighters who are working hard in very hot weather to contain this disaster and save lives and property. Cal Fire and Butte County, as well as other units from around the state, are doing everything they can to contain this fire and prevent it from spreading. Now that a State of Emergency has been declared and evacuated residents are beginning to return home, stay tuned for updates from first responders and local officials.

Illegal marijuana grows have an extremely detrimental impact on our public lands, causing severe damage to our environment and creating an unsafe atmosphere for the public who wish to enjoy the land. Drug cartels have created large-scale operations on federal lands which illegally divert stream water, dump tons of illegal toxicants and pollutants, and harm the local wildlife. These sites are often protected by heavily armed cartel members which pose a serious safety risk to those who utilize our public lands for hunting, fishing, and recreational activities – as well as the Forest Service and BLM staff who patrol the forests. It is imperative that the federal government address this problem in order to make our forests safe again for the public to enjoy.

In recent years, lack of rain combined with poor planning for future water infrastructure has caused California to experience severe droughts that have devastated agriculture, habitat, and the economy in general.   That same lack of infrastructure has prevented us from storing enough water during a rainy season, like we’ve seen this year, to prevent flooding and save for the future. There are many potential water projects around the state that could have helped remedy this problem, but they have been trapped in bureaucratic limbo for many years - even decades.   The bill we passed today would require the federal government to expedite the process of approving and completing water projects. Importantly, this legislation will also include protections for NorCal water rights and restore availability of water supply for California agriculture.

In Congress, we often disagree on many issues, but the severity and urgency of human trafficking is not one of them. Congress must take action to protect those that are vulnerable and hold accountable those who participate in such a heinous act. Yesterday, we continued our commitment to combatting human trafficking by passing legislation to increase training to detect trafficking, protect potential victims, and provide our law enforcement with better tools to combat sex trafficking. The Administration has shown that they too are committed to rooting out human trafficking, and the bills we’ve passed this Congress will help them to do that.

Without question, the United States has the finest military in the world, but today, our military is in a readiness crisis. The past six years have seen the budget drastically reduced while tensions around the world continue to rise. The NDAA will increase the size of our army, modernize equipment, and ensure our troops are outfitted with the best technology available. Most importantly, adequate funding is provided to bring our military readiness back to acceptable levels. This legislation provides the funding our military needs in a cost-effective and efficient manner, and I strongly support it.

On July 29th, I will be hosting a forum for local high school students who are interested in attending a United States Military Academy. Representatives from the Army, Air Force, Navy, Coast Guard, and Merchant Marines service academies will be in attendance, as well as members of my staff, to answer any questions about the nomination process. I invite any high school student who is interested in any of the military academies to join us to learn all that they have to offer.

During the evacuation of Oroville in February, the two-lane section of Highway 70 was unable to handle the traffic and left thousands of residents stuck in a standstill during an emergency evacuation. Luckily the Oroville Dam spillway stayed intact, but this highlighted the need for a 4-lane highway that links Oroville to the rest of region. That’s why I’m working with the Butte County Association of Governments to secure a federal grant to improve this section of highway. Today in the Transportation and Infrastructure committee, I highlighted this problem to Acting Deputy Administrator of the Federal Highway Administration, Walter Waidelich, and urged him to consider the economic and public safety impact that new transportation grants to widen the highway could have on the area.

In recent years, lack of coordination between federal agencies has delayed many important infrastructure projects – the recent Keystone XL pipeline immediately comes to mind. These delays are often unnecessary and only serve to hinder job growth. Today we decided to streamline this process by establishing a more transparent and efficient review process for new energy infrastructure projects. The House has also asserted the authority to delay implementation of the EPA’s ozone standards, which are a one-size-fits-all solution that won’t work for rural areas, where states still have no idea how to comply. I am glad that Congress and new EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt are on the same page – America is in great need of more modern and more efficient energy infrastructure.

In Case You Missed it: I asked the Army Corps of Engineers what the holdup is for signing off on the necessary repairs for the Feather River levee system following the Oroville Dam spillway incident in February. Local entities are ready to go, now it’s time the federal government stops dragging their feet and moves this process along.

America has no shortage of dangerous adversaries around the world. Iran is a state-sponsor of terrorism that continues to be a direct threat to our strong ally Israel, as well as American interests. Russia continues to undermine the sovereignty of both its neighbors and the U.S., while North Korea has further escalated attempts to develop intercontinental ballistic missiles capable of threatening the U.S. and our allies.   Each of these countries pose a serious threat to American interests, and these new sanctions will hold them accountable for their actions. Ultimately, Congress should have the final say when it comes to placing or removing sanctions on any foreign country, and this bipartisan legislation begins to establish that. Had this policy been in place during the last administration, Congress could have stopped the horrible Iran deal that gave billions to Iran and allowed them to develop nuclear weapons – while putting them on the fast track towards obtaining intercontinental ballistic missiles.   I hope the Senate and the President act quickly to move this important legislation forward and send a strong message to our adversaries.

Last night, the House of Representatives called for the unconditional release of United States citizens and legal permanent resident aliens being held for political purposes by the Government of Iran. These hostages are being unjustly held with the intent to negotiate with the United States, and should be released immediately. I urge the President to make their retrieval one of his highest priorities.

Strengthening our physician workforce has been a priority of mine since coming to Congress. In the North State, we have a severe shortage of physicians, resulting in less access to vital healthcare services and fewer options available to families and individuals, regardless of their health care coverage. The Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education program is a powerful tool in creating a physician and dentist pipeline helping rural and under-served areas train and retain more qualified health professionals.

This appropriations package prioritizes three things – rebuilding our military, caring for our veterans, and strengthening our national security. I am confident that this spending package will help to keep Americans secure – that includes securing vulnerable areas of our southern border that currently allow anyone to come and go as they please. Our troops will receive their largest pay raise in eight years and the VA will receive its highest ever level of funding to support the needs of our veterans. As a bonus for Northern California, the EPA will now be authorized to withdraw the overreaching Waters of the United States rule that has affected so many farmers in rural areas. This legislation is a huge step forward for our national security, our economy, and America’s capabilities around the globe.

We’ve known for years that the VA is in dire need of reform – now, together with VA Secretary David Shulkin, Congress is working to make these reforms a reality. In April, the House voted to permanently extend authorization for the Veterans Choice program, giving our veterans greater choice when it comes to health care. President Trump soon signed that legislation into law. This legislation provides funding to keep the program running for another six months while Congress works on a solution to keep the program funded long-term. Congress has made our intent clear, and we will continue to put bills on the President’s desk that will ensure veterans don’t have to wait to be seen by a doctor.

American schools should have American food whenever possible. The current Buy American provisions do not actually enforce this policy on schools – a fact that is only further highlighted by the results of this audit. In a state like California, which produces such a large portion of American agriculture, there is little to justify schools choosing to source lower quality foreign alternatives. The legislation that I co-authored with Congressman John Garamendi - the American Food for American Schools Act - will help ensure children are provided with more nutritious food that is produced right here at home in the U.S.

The Yuba County Sheriff's Department arrested four men while seizing over 3,500 illegal marijuana plants and cleaning up over 500 pounds of trash and chemicals during a bust near Camptonville, CA. Illegal marijuana grows pollute the environment with illegal toxicants, divert stream water, harm wildlife, and often endanger the public with the presence of armed cartel guards. Fortunately, these arrests were made without incident, but the public demands the operations be eliminated. Last month, I sent letters to Department of Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke and Department of Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue, urging them to assist in combating illegal marijuana growers on federal lands.

North and South, rural and urban, Republican and Democrat, California’s leaders agree on one thing: our state needs to invest in Sites Reservoir to meet the water supply challenges of today and the future. Sites provides more water per dollar invested than any other proposed project in the state, enough to supply millions of Californians for an entire year, while also creating environmental benefits and allowing smart recapture and reuse of water released from other reservoirs. Investing in Sites will fulfill the will of the 67% of Californians who supported Proposition 1 funding for water storage infrastructure, and I hope the California Water Commission recognizes the project’s diverse benefits.

After a 13% rise in premiums in 2017, you would forgive Californians for expecting a decrease this year. Unfortunately, that is not the case – as North State residents will experience an average rate increase of 33.2% in 2018. This is exactly why the ACA must be repealed and replaced with something that middle income families can afford. Premiums continue to rise at an increasingly alarming rate, and the only solution offered by Covered California is to switch to a worse plan. This doesn’t cut it – not for California and not for America – and we must continue the fight to repeal this disastrous law and replace it with something that works.

Today the Sutter Butte Flood Control Agency kicked off a nearly 3 mile levee reconstruction project. I take my hat off to the Army Corps and DWR for identifying the problem and making this happen so quickly. People don’t care about which agency gets the credit, they care about getting results, and they want to know that the levees are safe. This expedited process should become the model for federal and state governments to use when working together on important emergency projects, such as this one.

When it comes to managing large swaths of land, one thing is clear, the powers that be Washington DC don’t know best. State and local governments have a far better understanding of how to effectively manage the people's lands without limiting public access and hindering economic growth. In rural areas such as Northern California, the use of our land is critical to our way of life. I supported the President’s Executive Order to review recent overreaching National Monument designations, now we call on him to do what no Administration has done before – allow the states and their local governments to not be overlooked, but have a strong voice when making important decisions that directly affect their livelihoods.
