This weekend, I had the opportunity to join House Agriculture Committee Chairman Mike Conaway and a few of my House colleagues for a Farm Bill listening session in Modesto, CA. The feedback we received from local farmers will help us to solve the challenges that are facing NorCal and American Agriculture in the next Farm Bill, and I thank them for providing their input.

Thanks everyone who came out for the Chico town hall meeting this morning. While we may agree on some issues and disagree on others, we ultimately had a productive conversation that will help me as I represent you in Washington.

I was happy to join the California Farm Bureau Federation yesterday for a forestry round table discussion focused on policy ideas that I can bring to the House Agriculture Committee for the next Farm Bill.

Yesterday, I was able to once again attend Coffee with a Cop in Chico to thank our local law enforcement officers for their hard work to protect our communities on a daily basis. I had the opportunity to meet with Chico Police Chief Mike O'Brien and California Highway Patrol Chico office Commander April Baxter, among others.
In case you missed it: I stopped by Channel 12/24 Action News Now to chat about North Korea's recent threats, as well as Highway 70 and Northern California infrastructure.

I was honored to receive the Spirit of Enterprise Award and the Hard Hat Award on behalf of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, as well as the local Redding, Anderson and City of Shasta Lake Chambers of Commerce for my track record of promoting pro-growth economic policies that help create jobs

The need for Sites Reservoir is one of the few things that California's leaders can all agree on. Over two thirds of Californians support investing in new water storage projects, and Sites would provide more storage per dollar invested than any other proposed project. We need to finally address our state's water needs after decades of inaction, and this project would provide enough water to supply millions of Californians for an entire year.

I am very disappointed in the result of this case. It is not through any fault of Mr. Duarte, who is only trying to avoid paying millions more to the government simply for plowing his fields. This sets a dangerous precedent for the use of private property in America and gives the federal government free reign to alter the interpretation of laws as they see fit.

In Case You Missed it: In the Transportation in Infrastructure Committee, I explained to Acting Deputy Administrator of the Federal Highway Administration, Walter Waidelich, why Highway 70 should be at the top of the list to receive transportation grants to widen the highway.
Thanks to all who came out yesterday for the Tulelake Town Hall! I appreciate you sharing with me your ideas and concerns, and I will put your input to good use as I represent you in Congress.
My next stop today was Susanville, where I held a town hall meeting and met with many local officials afterwards. Thank you all for coming out and sharing your ideas and concerns!

Thank you to all who joined me in Chester this morning for my town hall meeting! We discussed a number of issues that we're facing both at home in the North State and in Washington, D.C., and I greatly appreciate your feedback.

I congratulate my fellow North State farmer Brian Dahle on being named Assembly Republican Leader. It's about time that we finally have a voice of someone who is from North of Sacramento to lead the caucus and be a megaphone for rural issues.  Brian has continued where I left off in fighting for expanded timber management legislation. With 100 million dead trees, the need to utilize biomass, and the desperate need for more water storage and a stronger Ag presence, Brian can help make these issues a priority and bring stronger awareness in the Assembly.

Today, Congressman John Garamendi and I hosted a transportation summit on State Route 70. As our population and economy in the North State have grown over the years, much of our transportation infrastructure hasn’t kept up. State Route 70 is a vital regional artery that supports agriculture, tourism, and daily commuting – but residents are all too familiar with the safety risks associated with it. Fatal accidents have doubled over the past decade and the highway clearly can’t handle a large-scale emergency evacuation like we saw in February. Fortunately, our region is well-positioned to leverage local, state, and federal dollars to expand areas of the highway from two lanes to four lanes. Our project will also compete for federal funds under the President’s new Infrastructure for Rebuilding America grant program. We all recognize this as a top priority, and the bipartisan cooperation and cross-jurisdictional planning are encouraging signs that we will be able to seize this opportunity and secure the necessary funds to improve safety on one of our most important highways.

The danger of Highway 70 is now well documented and known by the general public. With 13 deaths on the highway already this year, it is clear that the long talked about work to widen sections from Oroville to Marysville is urgent. This process has been in the works for too long but I believe we will finally be able to secure the necessary funding. With many local efforts already underway, Congressman Garamendi and I will do whatever it takes to secure federal funding and move this process forward sooner rather than later.
Immediate evacuation orders for the Ponderosa fire...Please be safe.

Americans are counting on Congress to reduce and reform their tax burden to spur our economy. Today, the President laid out the road map to help craft tax reform as Congress finalizes its plans to pursue the first significant change to our overly complicated tax code in decades. This is about keeping hard-earned money where it belongs – in the hands of American families – not in the loose fingers of the government. As things stand, our tax code is unnecessarily complex and puts American businesses at a steep disadvantage in the international marketplace. The President is right, this is a once in a generation opportunity to reduce the tax burden for Americans and with it, bring back dollars stranded overseas and jobs into our U.S. economy.

In case you missed it, Secretary Zinke’s review of national monument expansions is complete, and it’s believed that he will soon recommend reducing the acreage of the Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument - which covers 86,774 acres of land in southwestern Oregon and northwestern California. The recent expansion of this monument infringed on private property rights and ignored objections from countless local residents. Downsizing would allow the Department of Interior to better manage the land while increasing the public’s access, and I fully support it.

In February, tens of thousands of lives were at risk when the Oroville Dam spillway failed and nearly 200,000 were forced to evacuate their homes. It was clear then that whatever systems were in place for inspecting our water infrastructure were not good enough – that is even clearer after this report. California’s infrastructure inspection process doesn’t cut it. We must change this system and have independent experts administer a more thorough inspection that dives much deeper than just a yearly visual checkup.

Today, the House voted to provide $7,850,000,000 in emergency disaster relief funding for those who have been tragically impacted by Hurricane Harvey in Texas and Louisiana. $7,400,000,000 will be distributed to the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s (FEMA) Disaster Relief Fund and $450,000,000 to the Small Business Association’s (SBA) Disaster Loans Program. With Hurricane Irma also barreling towards Florida, we must give our full support right now to our friends in the southeastern United States.

This year in the western United States, there have been nearly 8 million acres burned by wildfires so far. In Siskiyou County alone, there are 173,000 acres of land that are either burning right now or have been burned by recent fires. The people of California, Montana, Oregon, and many other western states are facing this crisis every single year, a fact which many other areas of the country are likely not even aware of. My office has been working hard to get proper fire mapping in Siskiyou so that our fire fighters can more effectively control the Wallow fire, which is inching dangerously close to structures and property in the nearby city of Etna. Ultimately, we must take action to better manage our forests in order to prevent these fires from occurring in the first place.

Today, the House passed a bill that provides some much needed aid for those that have been affected by Hurricane Harvey, as well as damage expected to be caused by Hurricane Irma. FEMA is quickly running out of money, and it was important that we provide the funds to help Texas, Louisiana, and Florida recover as quickly as possible. It is also important that we keep the government funded while we look for a long term solution, and this package keeps the lights on for another three months.

The use of taxpayer dollars by the Obama Administration to improperly fund Governor Brown’s pet delta tunnel project is unacceptable. The state of California and the federal government lied to Congress and stole millions of hard-earned dollars from taxpayers – who ended up paying for a large portion of the project’s planning costs without their knowledge. California needs to repay every penny to the federal government immediately. The Bureau of Reclamation needs to explain to Congress how and why this happened and the employees and appointees who carried it out must be held responsible. Lying to Congress and the American people cannot be tolerated.

September 11, 2001 was a day that shook our nation to its core. I was at home preparing for the day's rice harvest when those planes made impact with the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. America wasn’t prepared for such a threat. Unlike today, we had no fighter jets on call to patrol the skies at a moment’s notice. Before United 93 was brought down in a field by the heroic passengers on board, there is a lesser known, lesser spoken story of courage and valor. Lt. Heather "Lucky" Penney, an Air Force F-16 pilot, was fully prepared to prevent that plane from reaching its target. But her F-16 was armed with no ammunition and no missiles - her plane was the missile. it was a suicide mission, but one she was willing to take on without hesitation. Her father, John Penney, was a retired Air Force pilot who served during Vietnam and was a United pilot that day. He could well have been in the rotation of flying Flight 93, a possibility Heather was well aware of. But it did not change her mission. It turns out he was not in the cockpit of that particular plane, but Heather had no way of knowing. Both Heather and the passengers aboard United Flight 93 are a testament to why our nation, while it might be bruised or bloodied, will never be defeated by acts of terror by any power. Today, we honor those who we lost 16 years ago, and even more so those that were sacrificed running towards danger to help others. Their stories will inspire us for generations to come.

The California Department of Water Resources knew there were plenty of issues with the Oroville Dam long before the spillway failure in February. Dam operators knew that of the 56 original devices installed to monitor for leaks in the 1960's, only three were still functional. Federal officials urged California many times to install cameras to better monitor the dam and its spillways in an emergency, but DWR neglected to address this problem. As a result, they were unable to identify and address the problem before it created an emergency situation. This only further demonstrates the need for greater transparency and accountability at DWR.

Today, the House Natural Resources committee passed the Sportsman's Heritage and Recreational Enhancement (SHARE) Act, which included my bill, the Guides and Outfitters Act, as an amendment. The SHARE Act is one of the most important actions Congress can take this year to protect and expand hunting and fishing on public lands, and I look forward to its consideration on the House floor.

After a fire destroyed millions of WWII, Korean War, and Vietnam War veterans’ files over 40 years ago, the Department of Defense hasn't yet put into place a good system to reconstruct their history and determine their eligibility for benefits. That is why I partnered with Rep. Carbajal to introduce the bipartisan Veterans’ Record Reconstruction Act. Simply put, this legislation will make it easier for veterans that have dealt with this headache for so long to access the services they’ve earned. With uniform guidelines in place, there will be no confusion as to what’s acceptable and what’s not, and that makes life easier for everyone involved.

Across America, many of our communities have been harmed by illegal alien gang members – that is a fact. Yet current immigration law prohibits ICE from effectively targeting those known to be associated with criminal gang activities and removing them from the country. This legislation changes that and gives ICE the tools they need to better help our communities by removing those that only wish to inflict harm. Their tactics of violence harm our society and intimidate free and innocent people.

Health care in rural America faces many challenges. This week, I spoke on the House floor to emphasize the need for Congress to extend the Community Health Centers and Teaching Health Centers programs, which are vital to rural residents in areas lacking major hospitals and facing doctor shortages.

In case you missed it, I spoke on the House Floor regarding the Obama Administration's misuse of $84 million for Governor Brown's pet Delta Tunnels project. Lying to Congress and the American people cannot be tolerated and California needs to repay every penny to the federal government, as well as taxpayers from the other 49 states.

Thanks to all who joined me last night for our town hall meeting in Yreka! The meeting went well with a lot of good give and take as we covered a wide range of issues affecting Northern California and our country. I appreciate the input as we go forward to craft policy that best helps our U.S. citizens thrive and enjoy freedom.

Last updated in 1986, our tax code has increased in length and complexity beyond the point of functionality. It is over six times as long today as it was in 1955 and has become nearly unworkable for most Americans. As things stand, our tax system is unnecessarily complex and puts American businesses at a steep disadvantage in the international marketplace - it needs an update. Learn more about our tax relief plan here: http://bit.ly/2h1bN3o

I visited Siskiyou County's Great Basin Team 7 at their command center for an update on the Salmon August Complex fire that run up $34 million in costs to fight was become a 66,000 acre fire in Siskiyou County.  Cal-Fire, the Forest Service and the National Guard have turned the fire away from Etna but it is still only 36% contained. I've said it before - we must have better forestry management to help fight these fires when they occur. The trees and vegetation are leaving the forests either as smoke or as usable forest products. I’d rather it be via logging and proper forest management that can improve our environment instead of fueling the spread of catastrophic wildfires that burn millions of acres in the West.

Wildfires have burned millions of acres of land in the West so far this year – with thousands of acres burning today. Agriculture Secretary Sonny Purdue and Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke have reaffirmed their commitment to improving our forestry management practices, and I believe Congress should treat wildfires the same as hurricanes and other disasters. We need the ability to more quickly remove dead trees and vegetation that only fuel the spread of these wildfires and make it more difficult for firefighters to contain them. If we properly manage our forests, our economy will benefit and these fires will be less catastrophic.
The public comment period for proposed changes to the Waters of the United States rule ends Wednesday. Leave your comment here: http://bit.ly/2tPEh5Q

North Korea’s greatest weapon is not a nuclear bomb, it’s propaganda and the manipulation of its’ own people. Yesterday, the House passed the North Korean Human Rights Reauthorization Act, which helps to break down the barriers to information that Kim Jong Un uses to brainwash his people into thinking that his way is the only way. This bill increases efforts to get truthful information to North Koreans through USB drives, radio broadcasts, mobile devices, and more. When Kim can no longer control his own people and prevent them from accessing the truth, his regime will crumble from the inside.

This tax reform proposal will be good for jobs, good for businesses, and good for families. Currently, our corporate tax rate is the highest in the developed world, putting American businesses at a steep disadvantage in the international marketplace. As a result, we’ve seen countless businesses move overseas, taking their jobs with them. Our plan means bringing these businesses – and jobs – back home to the United States. Creating more job opportunities and higher wages for hardworking Americans will mean more money in the pockets of families. This will benefit our economy immensely, and we must move these proposals forward as quickly as possible.

With funding expiring on September 30th, it was important to extend authorization for the FAA and prevent nationwide employee furloughs and project halts. In addition, contained in the bill is reauthorization for the Teaching Health Centers program which is particularly important in rural areas, like Northern California, where doctor shortages are a real problem. This program has been an effective tool to address that.  This legislation also increases availability of flood insurance in high risk areas and provides a tax break to our neighbors in the South, who have been severely impacted by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria in recent months. This is a timely and important bill, and I hope the Senate will put it on the President’s desk as quickly as possible.

I joined new California Department of Water Resources Director Grant Davis at the Oroville Dam as reconstruction for the main spillway and auxiliary spillway has been underway and on schedule. This is a multi-phase project that is being built up to 2017 standards with thicker walls, lots of concrete, and a more stable foundation. There are over 400 workers from right here in Northern California working on this project, and it appears that everything is on track to be completed on time and, more importantly, in a manner that will ensure another collapse doesn’t happen.

I am very pleased that my bill, the Guides and Outfitters (GO) Act, passed the House with unanimous support today. H.R. 289 helps Guides and outfitters - and everyone in rural areas - to have more access to recreation opportunities on our public lands. Hunting, fishing, whitewater rafting, biking, trail hikes, horseback riding, and general enjoyment of the outdoors will be easier to do with less Washington bureaucratic red-tape and impossible fees to get in the way. This is a common-sense and fair bill that streamlines the permitting process and allows more local economic opportunities for the people back on their lands. I look forward to a positive and timely result in the Senate.

The catastrophic wildfires that have been ravaging our public lands are a fixable problem with a very clear cause – mismanagement has left our forests highly susceptible for these fires to spread at a record rate. Fire prevention, such as thinning dead trees and removing hazardous fuel, has taken a backseat while we spend billions to suppress fires only after they’ve gotten out of hand. These wildfires are every bit the natural disasters that hurricanes are, yet they receive only a fraction of the funding. They destroy property, hurt rural economies, and are a constant danger to human life, wildlife, and their habitat – but it can all be mitigated with better forest management practices. I and many others have fought for these reforms for a long time. I’m glad to see the Administration is listening to the concerns of those who are affected by these fires and has shown a willingness to work with Congress to fix it.

Just in California's 1st District alone, 183,000 acres have been burned by wildfires already this year. This is a real problem that affects us each and every year and it requires immediate action. The ash from these catastrophic fires pollutes our air and water quality while human lives and property are in constant danger. I joined Congressman Bruce Westerman and many other House colleagues at a press conference this morning on the threat of severe wildfires to our country. I supported the Resilient Federal Forests Act as it passed through the House Agriculture Committee this week, which will bring meaningful reforms to end the practice of fire borrowing and allow us to better manage our forests to prevent these fires from happening. Many in the California Legislature seem to think that they already have executed CalExit. Alas, California in fact remains part of the United States. Governor Brown has no authority to ignore and violate federal immigration law, just as Arizona previously didn’t have the right to enforce immigration laws without the Federal Government. If this logic stands, can North State Counties simply vote to ignore Sacramento Democrats gas taxes and regulations? Today again shows how out of touch Sacramento is with the average American. Congress will address this issue.

Due to misguided forestry management practices that don’t allow for thinning and other prevention strategies, our forests are being consumed by wildfires at an alarming rate. Each year, thousands of firefighters risk their lives to protect our forests and property from the spread of these fires. They are known by titles such as "Wildland Technician" and "Forestry Technician" – vague terms that don’t reflect the scope of their duties. H.R. 3907 ensures these men and women are recognized by the proper title and terminology. When a destructive fire spreads quickly through woodlands, we call it a wildfire. When someone fights it, they deserve to be called a Wildland Firefighter.
Thank you to all who were in attendance for our town hall meeting at Loyalton High School. I will always listen to what you have to say, and I appreciate everyone’s productive input.

Two days ago, several major fires began rapidly spreading through Northern California. Due to the extreme conditions, some of these fires still remain at zero percent containment, with firefighters and emergency responders instead focusing on evacuating nearby citizens. These fires are burning thousands of acres of land and have already destroyed property, possessions, and worse – at least eleven people have lost their lives. Those affected by these catastrophic fires need help immediately, and I thank President Trump and his Administration for taking quick action to issue a disaster declaration after I and others in the California delegation requested it earlier today.

The Clean Power Plan has a nice sounding name, but in reality, it’s a prime example of burdensome and unnecessary regulation on America’s energy industry. The Obama Administration repeatedly overstepped its authority and ignored the longstanding limits to Executive power, and now we must right the ship. The Implementation of this rule has already been halted by a number of court decisions – including by the Supreme Court. It’s estimated that this rule would costs billions of dollars in compliance costs alone, not to mention the crippling effect on U.S. energy production and global competitiveness. This is the sort of job-killing power grab that the American people cannot and should not accept. I applaud Administrator Pruitt and the EPA for proposing to repeal this rule before it takes effect, and I look forward to a rulemaking process that is transparent and takes into account the needs and input of states before imposing heavy-handed regulations that leave American workers and energy production out in the cold.

Today, the House Natural Resources Committee passed the National Monument Creation and Protection Act, which establishes an appropriate precedent for the creation of new National Monuments under the often-abused Antiquities Act. No longer will a President have the authority to suddenly and unilaterally snatch large swaths of land away from public use without local input. In the case of the Cascade-Siskiyou Monument, President Obama expanded the monument over the direct objections of the counties in which it is located and included tens of thousands of acres of private property. Under this much-needed reform, any sizable area of land to be considered as a national monument would be subject to state and local input, as well as Congressional approval. I fully support this legislation to return this power back to Congress, the people, and local communities.

We’ve known for years that the Affordable Care Act is unsustainable. I’ve heard from numerous constituents that their premiums have risen by 50-60% just this year. One way or another, middle-income families need greater choice and lower costs. Today, the President is using the tools available to him to lower premiums, offer more affordable options, and increase competitiveness in the healthcare marketplace. Now, small businesses should be able to band together to purchase insurance for their employees across state lines, lowering costs for many workers who couldn’t afford their premiums under the Obamacare model. I’m glad the President is making the limited changes to this law that he can, but Congress must keep working to implement changes on a larger scale and find permanent solutions to fix this broken law.

Our nation's farmers are critical to ensuring Americans have a reliable supply of domestically produced food on the table, and at a stable price. I’m happy to join with you all in recognizing today, October 12th, as National Farmers Day.

This week, the House passed legislation that sends $36.5 billion toward wildfire suppression and hurricane relief – with $576.5 million going towards fighting recent catastrophic wildfires in the western United States.The devastating wildfires that are wreaking havoc in Northern California and the Western U.S. are now being recognized as the disasters that they are. People have lost everything – in some cases their lives. Similar to the hurricane-impacted areas in Texas, Florida, and Puerto Rico, quick recovery efforts will be critical to helping people get back on their feet and helping to get these economies moving again. Whether it’s a wildfire, a hurricane, or some other natural disaster, it is our responsibility to send help, and this funding will hopefully hasten a return to normalcy for those affected by these disasters.
We know that now is the time for tax relief, and it is up to Congress to get the job done. Read why I believe that America’s tax code is outdated and broken – and what we plan to do to fix it.

Last week, the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee held a hearing titled “Building a 21st Century Infrastructure for America: Highways and Transit Stakeholders’ Perspectives.” I asked a representative from the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials his thoughts on how components of the Highway Trust Fund and federal fuel tax would impact those living in California, and what impacts this has on the state or federal level.

The previous Administration’s agreement with Iran was as one-sided as it gets. They lifted billions in sanctions, allowing Iran to finance their terrorist operations – and in return, they’re still fully capable of developing ballistic missiles today with the authority to have nuclear weapons in a few short years. This agreement does nothing to protect the lives of American citizens and our allies, and I fully support the decision to revisit it. Iran must truly be held accountable for their dangerous behavior, and a poorly negotiated deal that is filled with concessions doesn’t accomplish that.

On the floor this week, the House will be voting on a number of bills that aim to put pressure on Iran for its support for terrorism, as well as urging the European Union to join the United States and other countries in officially designating Hezbollah in its entirety as a terrorist organization. The Iranian regime is a state-sponsor of terrorism and human rights abuse, and they must be held accountable.

Federal agencies have no business requiring defendants to donate money to partisan outside organizations instead of properly compensating victims – but under the previous administration, they did just that. Attorney General Jeff Sessions recently halted the use of these settlement slush funds, but now Congress must put a permanent stop to this practice so that settlements cannot be abused in the future. In any court case in which the United States is a party, settlement money should never be awarded to uninvolved organizations and should go only to the victims or to the Treasury, and that’s what this legislation will ensure.

The budget that the House and Senate have now agreed to is about one thing, and that’s paving the way for Congress to provide tax relief for millions of Americans. With the Ways and Means committee expected to unveil the tax cut bill soon, America is on the fast track to achieving the first major reform of our outdated tax code in decades. We’re one step closer to eliminating special interest loopholes and creating an environment that is friendlier for both individuals and American small businesses.

Iran is a state-sponsor of terrorism. It’s clear that the actions of the Iranian Regime are in stark contrast to the stated goal of the Iran Deal – to promote "regional and international peace and security." In fact, Iran repeatedly does quite the opposite, fueling conflict in the Middle East while financing Hezbollah’s unconscionable acts of terror – which include the use of civilians as human shields. These groups seek to destroy our close ally, Israel, and their aggression cannot go unchecked any longer. The bills we voted on this week show the intent of Congress to work together with the President and hold this regime accountable for their dangerous behavior.

The practice of "sue and settle" has become a common, if lesser known, abuse of rule-making authority under previous administrations. Under the Obama Administration in particular, there were $210.5 billion in regulatory costs added behind closed doors since 2009. This is destructive to our economy and needs accountability. EPA Administrator Pruitt has already decided to end this shady practice at the EPA, and now Congress is making that the law of the land for every federal agency moving forward. I hope the Senate will soon follow suit.
Today I was happy to join the Auburn Chamber of Commerce for a Brown Bag Lunch to discuss the need for tax reform and the rising costs of healthcare under the Affordable Care Act.

Today I joined the Mountain Counties Water Association to discuss water infrastructure projects in the North State, such as Governor Brown's ill-fated Delta Tunnels project and the need for Sites Reservoir, as well as better forest management to keep more water in the system.
Over the weekend, I joined the Lassen County Cattlemen's Association and Lassen County Farm Bureau to speak at their annual joint dinner in Susanville, CA.
This is a big week for tax reform. Make sure you are signed up to receive updates as they happen by texting "tax reform" to 50589.

A complete lack of forest management has left our forests more combustible than ever – leaving our firefighters wholly unprepared to contain overwhelming wildfires that quickly get out of hand. Forest fires will occur, but we can take logical steps to manage them that will help prevent them from spreading and extinguish them more quickly – resulting in less damage and lower costs. The Resilient Federal Forests Act will allow the U.S. Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management to properly manage our federal forests, which will improve overall forest health and reduce the risk of such severe wildfires.

The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is fulfilling the promise that Congress has made to the American people to provide major tax relief after 31 years of inaction. That includes doubling the standard deduction, lowering the corporate tax rate, and cutting taxes for small businesses. This is about creating an environment where American businesses will be incentivized to return home from overseas, creating more jobs, and boosting the American economy. This plan will save money for millions of middle-income Americans and eliminate special interest loopholes. Contrary to some reports, this is actually a tax cut for everyone but the wealthy. A North State family making the median household income of $59,000 will receive a $1,182 tax cut – and that’s just the beginning. I welcome all input on ways to further improve this legislation, but I support this bill and I look forward to its timely passage through committee and a vote on the House floor.

The Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB) is yet another misguided component of Obamacare. If triggered, this provision would authorize a board of 15 unelected bureaucrats to make sweeping reductions to Medicare spending, with no congressional oversight or accountability. These arbitrary cuts pose a significant threat to senior’s access to care, potentially limiting which medical treatments and services doctors can offer.  Many on both sides of the aisle agree that IPAB was a bad idea when it was created, and it’s a bad idea now. I am glad that the House is taking action to eliminate this dangerous provision.

The numbers speak for themselves - A new report estimates the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will create 111,108 new full time jobs in California and raise the median household income by $2,932. http://bit.ly/2yapsZw

The expansion of the joint employer definition was a solution in search of a problem and amounted to an assault on small businesses. Now, this decision threatens the autonomy of independent small business owners and unnecessarily puts them at a disadvantage. The Save Local Businesses Act is a common sense bill that rolls back this convoluted policy which only stifles job creation and economic growth.

It’s been said countless times before, but it’s worth repeating that our nation’s veterans deserve the best possible care we can offer them. Whether it’s improving access to health care options or simply requiring the VA to properly notify veterans of potential scams, it is our responsibility to make their lives easier in any way that we can. With Veterans Day approaching later this week, I’m happy that Congress has passed legislation that will have a meaningful impact on the quality of life for many veterans across the country.

Hydropower is a common sense use of California’s waterways to potentially power thousands of homes. Unfortunately, it can take up to a decade to license a new project or relicense existing infrastructure. This legislation is about modernizing that process and streamlining licensing requirements so that important projects can move forward as opposed to stalling for years. Local input is a critical component of this, as the 1st district is home to two of California’s biggest hydro plants at Oroville Dam and Shasta Dam, and it’s important that we are able to utilize this practical and environmentally friendly method of producing energy.

Thank you to all of the veterans who sacrifice so much for our country. Watch my speech on the House floor last week to learn just a little bit about the work that Congress is doing to provide our veterans with the best care possible. Happy Veterans Day!

The immediate danger at Oroville Dam has passed, but our work to ensure that the community’s concerns are addressed is not over. It’s extremely important that FERC consider the lessons of the spillway failure, and I’m confident that the Commissioners took to heart our message that rushing to relicense the dam would be a mistake. It’s in the best interest of public safety to ensure that the most recent data available is considered, and the current decade-old review of the dam simply isn’t adequate.

Here is what tax reform means for Northern California: Doubling the standard deduction means 73% who do not itemize get a tax cut immediately. Of the 27% who itemize, the median deduction is approximately $21,000, which is less than $24,000 standard deduction for joint filers. They will now choose to take the standard deduction and save money and time on their taxes.  Additionally, tax rates are reduced for all except those earning over a million dollars a year. Expanded Child tax credits and new family tax credit will help north state families. The average North State family will save nearly $1,200 a year in taxes.
NA

I’ve said it before, our military is in a readiness crisis. With conflicts all around the globe, our armed forces are stretched more thinly than ever. Congress understands this problem and members of both parties are taking action to fix it. The NDAA will make sure our military is properly equipped to handle the missions at hand. Importantly, it also gives our over-worked troops a much deserved pay raise – the largest in eight years. This legislation passed the Senate and now the House with broad bipartisan support, and I expect the President to sign it into law in short order.
Under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the Child Tax Credit will increase from $1,000 to $1,600. Over 45,000 North State families will see a 60% increase under this credit.

Under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the vast majority of North State residents will save money, period. The more than 70% of 1st District residents who do not currently itemize their tax returns will receive an immediate – and significant – tax cut. Far more taxpayers will now find it more advantageous to claim the standard deduction, rather than itemize, saving them more money in the process. Today we are delivering on the promise we made to the American people to make paying taxes fair and simple. Tax reform is good for Northern California and good for the country. Though it is not yet the final product, I support this bill. The Senate must pass their own version which, together with our House bill, will then require conference committee action moving forward.

Earlier this year, California hit its lowest unemployment rate ever recorded. The North State has benefitted tremendously from this trend, with the unemployment rate falling nearly 2 points in both Chico and Redding. At the same time, the number of people looking for jobs grew. That is a testament to the newfound confidence in our growing economy due to rollback of job-killing regulations enacted by the previous administration. The coming tax cuts will only further increase job and wage growth. Congress must continue working to eliminate unnecessary and harmful regulations so that our economy can continue to expand. Moving into conference on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is a big step forward for landmark tax reform. Between the doubled standard deduction, the increased Child Tax Credit, and the Family Flexibility Credit, Northern California residents will see a significant tax cut. When it’s all said and done, this bill will simplify our tax code and save money for the vast majority of filers in the 1st district, and that’s why I support it. This isn’t about the government’s money – this is about letting taxpayers keep more of their own hard-earned paychecks. I’ll be working closely with the conference committee as they iron out the differences between the two bills, and I look forward to a final vote on the House floor soon.

The Palestinian Authority’s “pay to slay” policy rewards families of terrorists for murdering Americans and Israelis. Today, I spoke on the House floor in support of the Taylor Force Act, which ceases any continued U.S. aid until these so-called “Martyr Payments” are permanently ceased. We shouldn't send one more penny until this heinous policy is abolished for good.

The President’s decision today to recognize Jerusalem as Israel’s capital is one that I strongly support, and is simply recognizing what has long been reality. This sends a strong message that the U.S. is committed to achieving peace in the region and will not be bullied by terrorism or threats of violence. Both houses of Congress voted overwhelmingly to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel in 1995, and this declaration is simply a long-overdue affirmation of that law. Recognizing the sovereignty of one of our strongest allies is a smart decision, and one that will ultimately allow for more stability in the region.

If a law-abiding citizen is legally licensed to carry a gun in one state, they should be allowed to in every state. The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act is about uniformity and personal protection when travelling across state lines.This legislation protects the constitutional rights of the millions of law-abiding gun owners in America that try to follow the rules.

At 7:48am On December 7th, 1941, the Empire of Japan deliberately attacked the United States at Naval Station Pearl Harbor in Hawaii. This surprise attack was meant to cripple the U.S. Pacific Fleet before entering the war, and President Roosevelt correctly labeled it as “a date which will live in infamy.” In the end, it was the determination and fighting spirit of the American military, along with the cohesive American spirit of innovation and amazing war material production that ultimately won the war. Today, 76 years later, we still remember and honor the 2,403 sailors and citizens killed that day, as well as the 1,178 injured. We will always remember.
Today, I had the great honor of kicking off the week by leading the Pledge of Allegiance on the House floor.

The USDA Forest Service announced that an additional 27 million trees died in California national forests this year, bringing the total to 129 million. This number has risen more than 25% compared to the previous year. We’ve seen the disastrous effects of catastrophic forest fires all across our state. Whether it’s via responsible forest thinning or a cloud of ash that pollutes our air quality, these dead trees are leaving the forests one way or another. USDA and the Forest Service must take immediate action to properly manage our forests by removing these dead trees before they become fuel for yet another fire.  Follow this link for the full press release from the U.S. Forest Service and CalFire: http://calfire.ca.gov/communications/downloads/newsreleases/2017/CAL%20FIREandU.S%20ForestAnnouce129MillionDeadTrees.pdf

It’s no secret that Iran exploits the use of civilian planes for military purposes. Iran Air was sanctioned for transporting missiles to Syria in 2011, but the Obama Administration lifted these sanctions under the misguided Iran Nuclear Deal. What was the result? Weapon resupply routes using commercial aircraft resumed. Given Iran’s status as a state-sponsor of terrorism, Congress and the American people have the right to know if any of the money from aircraft sales completed after the nuclear deal funded human rights abuses, terrorism, or weapon sales. That’s exactly what this legislation accomplishes.

Today, December 15, is National Bill of Rights Day. I spoke on the House floor to recognize this day with the words of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who signed this bill into law on November 27, 1941 - just days before the attack on Pearl Harbor.   "Now, Therefore, I, Franklin D. Roosevelt, President of the United States of America, do hereby designate December 15, 1941, as Bill of Rights Day. And I call upon the officials of the Government, and upon the people of the United States, to observe the day by displaying the flag of the United States on public buildings and by meeting together for such prayers and such ceremonies as may seem to them appropriate."

This weekend, I was happy to join the Chico chapter of Sons of the America Revolution and the Durham Boy Scouts to place Christmas wreaths on Veterans’ graves in both Durham and Dayton cemeteries. It was a privilege to help out.

I spoke on the House floor to congratulate the Shasta High Wolves on a tremendous football season. They won their section title for the first time in 29 years and represented Northern California in the state championship game for the first time in school history. They came up a bit short in the title game over the weekend, but these young men played hard and have a lot to be proud of after an historic season.

Under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the vast majority of 1st District residents will save money on their taxes. That is a fact. We’re giving a booster shot to the U.S. economy, which will enable businesses large and small to hire more workers and pay their employees more. This legislation will help put more Americans back to work and bring about the return of "Made in America." It provides the tax relief that hard-working middle income families in my district deserve, and that’s why I support it.

The President will soon officially sign the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act into law. This is fulfilling our promise of lowering taxes for middle income Americans, allowing them to keep more of what they’ve earned, and bringing the prospect of more jobs back to this country and to Northern California. The vast majority of 1st District residents stand to benefit significantly under this legislation, and businesses large and small will thrive. This is about keeping more money in the pockets of hard working Americans, and I was happy to vote for it.

This week, I spoke on the House floor to share the story of one of my constituents whose monthly insurance premiums have skyrocketed to $2,067.13 under Obamacare - an increase of over $830 and bringing his annual health insurance costs to nearly $25,000. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which was passed yesterday, repeals the individual mandate so that Americans are no longer punished for opting not to purchase insurance they cannot afford.

Today, the House passed a straight funding bill that will fund the government until January and keep important programs like CHIP and the Veterans Choice program running until we can reach a better, more accountable long term solution next year. We’re also sending the largest-ever disaster aid package that will help those in California that have been impacted by this year’s wildfires – and expands the ability to deduct losses from 2017. I'm disappointed the process of getting through the Senate has led us to this point, but there’s still a lot left on the table to accomplish in January – including properly funding our military. It is imperative that we fund these critical programs in the meantime and provide disaster victims with the assistance they need to recover.

Crunching the numbers on our recently passed tax plan, CBS discovered that “Most Americans will get a tax cut next year under the plan Congress passed this week,” despite many initially assuming they wouldn’t.   A struggling single mother, a married college professor with no children, and a small business owner in California all saved money. Watch the video to see for yourself.

The House of Representatives have passed a lot of bills in 2017 – 477 to be exact. Unfortunately, many have been hung up in the Senate. However, some very important pieces of legislation, such as the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, have passed both chambers and have been signed by the President. We’ve had a busy and productive year in the House, and I’m looking forward to another strong year in the people’s chamber in 2018.

This year, Congress passed the National Defense Authorization Act of 2018. This bill sets appropriate funding levels for the U.S. military and gives our troops the largest pay raise in 8 years. One of our first priorities in 2018 is to pass a long term funding bill so that our military is properly equipped to carry out its missions both at home and abroad.

In 2017, Congress continued our commitment to combatting human trafficking by passing legislation to increase training to detect trafficking, protect potential victims, and provide our law enforcement with better tools to combat sex trafficking.

It is our responsibility to make the lives of America’s veterans easier in any way that we can. This year, Congress passed 30 bills that do exactly that. We’ve permanently extended the Veterans Choice program, giving our vets more options when it comes to health care. And we’re working with new VA Secretary David Shulkin to institute badly-needed reforms to the Department of Veterans Affairs. In 2018, we’ll continue to put bills on the President’s desk to improve the quality of life for veterans in the North State and around the country.
